flow.context: Angela Vaught is a Property Manager at Atlantic Realty, a family-owned company managing ~160 vacation homes across the Outer Banks, NC. She's the day-to-day person who catches heat when damage is missed, guests complain, or owners are unhappy — the BBB even lists her as a Customer Contact. Atlantic Realty markets in-house housekeeping and inspections as core differentiators and recently posted for a COO/GM, signaling operational scaling. Rolf Blizzard (Managing Partner) controls budget; Meghan Sawyer (Asst. Director of Housekeeping) owns inspection standards. No personal connection to Sam found — lead with East Coast PM industry proximity.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Angela — I work with a couple other property managers on the East Coast on their inspection workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet-up energy. You belong in her world. Pause after the question and let her answer. Don't rush to fill silence.

heard_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well usually we'd be working with someone like you on their inspection process. What did you hear?
heard_yes.note: Rare on a true cold call but roll with it. Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge into discovery questions.

branches.label: She's confused / mixing you up with someone

heard_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD — BRIDGE TO PAIN
heard_no.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call —
heard_no.note: Keep it light and move straight into the pain trigger. No pause needed here.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow afternoon? Or is there a day this week that's less crazy?
bad_timing.note: Don't pitch. Just get a callback window. If she gives a time, take it and hang up.

reschedule_confirmed.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
reschedule_confirmed.say: Perfect — I'll give you a ring then. Appreciate it, Angela.
reschedule_confirmed.note: Write down the exact day and time. Call back precisely when you said you would.

who_is_this.label: CONFUSED OR GUARDED
who_is_this.say: Yeah totally — it is a cold call, I'll be honest. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I called, and if it's not relevant you can totally hang up on me?
who_is_this.note: Admitting it's a cold call disarms. Most people grant 30 seconds once you're honest about it.

permission_rejected.label: REJECTED EVEN 30 SECONDS
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You're splitting the rejection. 'Horrible time' gives you a callback. 'Not interesting' gives you info or a clean exit.

branches.label: She softens / asks what it is

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER — PEER STORY
pain_trigger.say: I was working with another property manager on the East Coast — similar setup to you guys, about 150 homes, in-house housekeeping team. And she was telling me about peak season — her team was turning 70, 80 homes every Saturday, photos were getting taken after every clean, but nobody actually had time to go through all of them. So stuff kept slipping — a cracked screen door here, a missing set of towels there — and the first person to notice was always the guest. Then it's a fire drill. She's calling maintenance, the owner's calling her, and it's ten o'clock on a Saturday night. Does any of that sound familiar, or is your world totally different?
pain_trigger.note: This is the money moment. Speak slowly, paint the picture. PAUSE after 'does any of that sound familiar.' Do NOT jump to the solution. Let her react.

branches.label: Not really / we handle it fine
I'm not the right person for this
Not interested / too busy for this

warm_curious.label: SHE'S ENGAGED — STOP PITCHING, ASK
warm_curious.say: Yeah — I hear that a lot, especially from folks in the Outer Banks where it's that Saturday-to-Saturday crunch all summer. So what does your inspection process actually look like right now? Like after housekeeping finishes a turn, what happens before the next guest checks in?
warm_curious.note: She's warm. Do NOT pitch. Ask questions and listen. You're mapping her process and finding the gap.

branches.label: She describes their process in detail
She vents about a specific pain
She's guarded / gives a short answer

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — THEIR PROCESS
discovery_process.say: Got it. And when photos come in from those turnovers — is someone actually reviewing every one, or is it more like they're there if you need to go back and look after something goes wrong?
discovery_process.note: You're looking for the gap: photos exist but nobody reviews them proactively. Listen for PMS or tool names — Breezeway, Track, shared folders, etc.

branches.label: Nobody reviews them all / just for CYA
Someone on the team checks every photo
We don't really do formal photo inspections

discovery_depth.label: DISCOVERY — DIG DEEPER
discovery_depth.say: OK so someone's going through them — with 160-ish homes and peak season coming up, how does that hold up when you're doing 80-plus turns in a day? Does that person ever fall behind or miss things just because of the sheer volume?
discovery_depth.note: Use their unit count to show you did homework. You're looking for the admission that it breaks down at scale or during peak weekends.

branches.label: Admits it breaks down / misses happen
Says it works fine for them
Mentions a specific tool or system

discovery_pain_point.label: DISCOVERY — BIGGEST HEADACHE
discovery_pain_point.say: What's been the biggest headache with turnovers? Is it more that stuff gets missed and you hear about it from the guest, or is it more the time it takes your team to make sure everything's actually ready?
discovery_pain_point.note: Let her pick her pain. Whatever she says, validate it and then bridge to the solution. Don't rush.

discovery_nudge.label: SHE'S BRIEF — SKIP TO CTA
discovery_nudge.say: Totally get it — I don't want to grill you on a cold call. Short version is, we've been helping a few property managers automate the photo review piece so their team doesn't have to eyeball every single picture after every turn. Would you be open to taking a quick look sometime this week when I'm not ambushing you?
discovery_nudge.note: She's warm-ish but not a talker. Skip deep discovery and go straight to the CTA. Some people just want to see it, not talk about it.

solution_bridge.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_bridge.say: Yeah — so that's exactly why we built RapidEye. It plugs into whatever system your team's already using to take turnover photos and automatically reviews every single one the moment it's uploaded — flags damage, missing items, staging issues — before the next guest walks in. No workflow change for your cleaners, it just catches what humans don't have time to catch.
solution_bridge.note: One breath. Don't oversell. If she mentioned a specific PMS or tool, reference it by name. Then go straight to CTA.

branches.label: We don't have budget for that
Sounds cool but not right now

cta_meeting.label: ASK FOR THE MEETING
cta_meeting.say: Would you be open to hopping on a quick call this week so I can show you what it actually looks like? Twenty minutes, tops — worst case you steal some ideas for how other OBX managers are handling their turnovers heading into summer, and we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: Low pressure. 'Worst case you steal ideas' removes risk. If she asks about price, say you'll walk through all of that on the call — don't get into pricing now.

branches.label: I'd need to loop in someone else

book_meeting.label: BOOK IT — LOCK IN A TIME
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got Thursday pulled up — does afternoon work, like two o'clock? Or is morning better for you?
book_meeting.note: Pick a specific day and time. Don't say 'when works for you' — give her an anchor. Send the calendar invite while still on the phone.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar and get back to you

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED — WRAP UP
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — I'll send over a calendar invite right now. Really appreciate you taking my call, Angela. Looking forward to it.
meeting_booked.note: Stop selling immediately. Send the invite right now. Get off the phone before she can second-guess.

obj_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
obj_not_interested.say: Totally get it — honestly I should've assumed you'd have this handled, otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it more that you're genuinely not dealing with any inspection headaches, or is it more that you just hate getting cold called?
obj_not_interested.note: Agree first — surprise her. Then split the objection. You're separating 'real objection' from 'reaction to the interruption.' Most people soften once you agree.

branches.label: It's not a problem for us
I just hate cold calls / bad timing

obj_have_process.label: OBJECTION — WE HAVE A PROCESS
obj_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 160-ish homes you'd have to have something in place. Honestly most people I talk to do. Just out of curiosity — is it that you're totally happy with how it works, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a massive headache?
obj_have_process.note: Validate first. Use their unit count. The split: 'happy' means hard to crack, 'switching is hard' means they have pain but inertia is winning — that's workable.

branches.label: Switching would be a pain / too busy
Actually we do have some issues…

obj_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
obj_no_budget.say: Totally get it — nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Especially if you guys are going through any operational changes right now. Is it that budget for this year is completely spoken for, or is it more that anything new has to go through a big approval chain?
obj_no_budget.note: The 'operational changes' comment is a soft nod to their COO/GM posting. Don't be heavy-handed. If she mentions Rolf or leadership approval, pivot to referral.

branches.label: Budget is locked / nothing new this year
Has to go through approval / not my call

operational_change_hook.label: OPERATIONAL CHANGE — LEAN IN
operational_change_hook.say: Oh interesting — are you guys bringing someone new in on the operations side? Because honestly that's usually the best time to get something like this in front of leadership. New ops person comes in, they want to see what tools are available — it's a lot easier to be the one who already has something to show them versus starting from scratch.
operational_change_hook.note: They posted for a COO/GM. If she confirms any leadership change, position RapidEye as something the new leader would want on day one. Don't reveal you saw the posting unless she brings it up first.

branches.label: She names who's coming in or who decides

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally respect that. Here's my thinking though — you're probably not buying anything today, and that's fine. But the property managers who end up in the best spot when budget does open up are the ones who already know what's first on their list. If nothing else, I could walk you through what a couple other OBX managers are doing with their turnover photos heading into summer — worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. Would you be open to twenty minutes this week?
sell_test_drive.note: You're selling the value of the meeting, not the product. 'Steal some ideas' removes risk. If she still says no, try send_email. If she says no to that, graceful_exit.

offer_peer_value.label: OFFER PEER INSIGHT
offer_peer_value.say: Fair enough — I won't pretend to know your business better than you do. One thing I will say — I've been talking to a bunch of property managers in the Outer Banks and there's some interesting stuff happening with how the bigger shops are automating their turnover QC heading into this summer. Happy to share what I'm seeing if it's ever useful — no pitch, just what's working. Worth a quick conversation?
offer_peer_value.note: Position yourself as a market intel source, not a vendor. She manages 160 homes — she absolutely pays attention to what the 400-600 home shops are doing.

not_my_decision.label: NOT MY DECISION — PIVOT TO REFERRAL
not_my_decision.say: Totally makes sense — I wouldn't expect you to go rogue on something like this. Who on your team typically makes the call on operations tooling? Like is that more of a Rolf Blizzard decision, or is there someone on the ops side who handles that?
not_my_decision.note: Drop Rolf's name casually to show you've done homework. If she mentions Meghan Sawyer or housekeeping leadership, that's a great referral path. Don't push — she's doing you a favor.

branches.label: She names Rolf or another exec
She says housekeeping / Meghan handles inspections
Actually I can decide, I just need to look first

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — ASK FOR THE NAME
referral_ask.say: Totally get it. If I could just get a name, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands with the right person — way better than me cold calling around your office. Any idea who'd be best to reach out to?
referral_ask.note: Be direct but not pushy. A name is gold. Even a department or title helps you narrow down your next call.

branches.label: She suggests emailing the main office

referral_housekeeping.label: REFERRAL TO HOUSEKEEPING
referral_housekeeping.say: Oh perfect — yeah that makes total sense, the housekeeping side is usually closest to the inspection workflow. Is that Meghan Sawyer, or is there someone else running that team now?
referral_housekeeping.note: Drop Meghan's name confidently. If Angela confirms, ask if she'd be willing to give Meghan a heads up that you'll be reaching out.

branches.label: She's not sure who handles it

referral_get_name.label: GOT THE REFERRAL — CLOSE WARM
referral_get_name.say: That's super helpful — really appreciate it. Would you mind if I mentioned that you and I spoke? Just so it doesn't feel like a totally random call for them. And hey — if this ever becomes relevant on your side, I'm easy to find. Thanks Angela.
referral_get_name.note: Get permission to use her name as social proof on the next call. Write down the referral name, title, and any contact info she gives. This is a warm lead now.

branches.label: She'd rather you not use her name

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll shoot something over. One quick question so it's not just another generic pitch in your inbox — what would actually be most useful to see? Like would it be more helpful if I showed you what the actual inspection reports look like, or more of a quick overview of how it plugs into your existing setup?
send_email.note: Accept the email request but get ONE piece of intel so your follow-up is tailored. This also sets up a legitimate reason to call back.

branches.label: She tells you what she'd want to see

email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND FOLLOW-UP
email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. What's the best email for you? And would it be alright if I followed up Thursday or Friday just to make sure it didn't get buried?
email_confirm.note: Get her email address. Set an explicit follow-up day. The follow-up call is where the real conversation happens — this call just opens the door.

branches.label: She gives email and agrees to follow-up
Don't follow up / I'll reach out if interested

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything ever changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Angela.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Be warm and genuine. She'll remember how you ended the call. Update CRM with outcome, intel gathered, and any referral names.
